terms.shortDefinition: Total property income minus operating expenses, excluding debt service and capital expenditures. The foundational metric for property performance.
terms.fullDefinition: Net Operating Income (NOI) is the income a property generates after all operating expenses but before debt service (mortgage payments) and income taxes. It's calculated as Gross Rental Income minus Operating Expenses (property taxes, insurance, management, maintenance, utilities, etc.). NOI is the foundation for many key metrics including cap rate and DSCR. A higher NOI means more cash available to cover debt payments, build reserves, and generate profit.

variables.description: Total rent collected plus other income
Property taxes, insurance, management, repairs, etc.

proTips: NOI does NOT include mortgage payments—that's intentional for comparing properties regardless of financing
To increase NOI: raise rents, add income streams, or reduce operating expenses
Use NOI to compare properties objectively, even if they have different financing
Track NOI monthly to catch expense creep early

examples.title: Duplex NOI Calculation
examples.scenario: Your duplex generates $4,000/month rent. Annual expenses: $4,800 taxes, $1,800 insurance, $2,400 maintenance, $4,800 management (10%)
examples.outcome: Your NOI is $34,200/year, which you can use to calculate cap rate and evaluate if this property meets your return targets

terms.shortDefinition: Total income a property could generate at full occupancy, before any expenses or vacancy deductions.
terms.fullDefinition: Gross Rental Income (also called Gross Potential Rent) is the maximum income a property could generate if fully occupied at market rents. It includes base rent from all units plus any additional income like parking, laundry, or storage. This is your starting point for calculating NOI and evaluating a property's income potential. The difference between gross potential rent and what you actually collect is due to vacancy and credit losses.
proTips: Compare your actual rent to market rates regularly—you might be leaving money on the table
Gross income should include ALL income: rent, late fees, pet rent, parking, laundry
Use gross potential rent for underwriting, then factor in realistic vacancy
Track month-over-month to catch trends in your income

terms.shortDefinition: The percentage of time or units that are unoccupied, representing lost rental income.
terms.fullDefinition: Vacancy rate measures the portion of potential rental income lost due to unoccupied units. It's expressed as a percentage of gross potential rent. A 5% vacancy rate means you're losing 5% of potential income to turnover, vacancy between tenants, or marketing time. When analyzing properties, use realistic vacancy assumptions based on local market data—typically 5-8% for residential properties in stable markets.
proTips: Even single-family rentals should budget 5-8% vacancy for turnover
Track your actual vacancy vs. budget to improve future projections
High vacancy might indicate pricing, property condition, or management issues
Consider offering lease renewal incentives to reduce turnover vacancy

terms.shortDefinition: Recurring costs to operate a property, including taxes, insurance, management, maintenance, and utilities.
terms.fullDefinition: Operating expenses are the ongoing costs of owning and managing a rental property. They include property taxes, insurance, property management fees, repairs and maintenance, utilities (if landlord-paid), landscaping, HOA fees, and other recurring costs. Operating expenses do NOT include mortgage payments, capital expenditures, or depreciation. Understanding your operating expense ratio (expenses ÷ gross income) helps you benchmark against similar properties.
proTips: A typical operating expense ratio is 35-50% for residential properties
Don't confuse operating expenses with capital expenditures (CapEx)
Self-managing saves the 8-10% management fee but costs your time
Review expenses quarterly to catch and address any unusual increases

terms.shortDefinition: Funds set aside for major repairs and replacements like roofs, HVAC systems, and appliances.
terms.fullDefinition: Capital Expenditure (CapEx) reserves are funds set aside for major repairs and replacements that occur periodically but not annually. This includes roofs (every 20-30 years), HVAC systems (15-20 years), water heaters (10-15 years), appliances, flooring, and other major components. Proper CapEx reserves prevent cash flow emergencies and protect your investment. A common rule of thumb is 5-10% of gross rent, though actual needs vary by property age and condition.
proTips: Older properties typically need higher CapEx reserves (10%+)
Create a CapEx schedule listing all major systems and their replacement timeline
CapEx is separate from your operating expense budget
When buying, get a property inspection to understand upcoming CapEx needs

examples.title: CapEx Reserve Calculation
examples.scenario: Your property rents for $2,000/month. The roof will need replacement in 10 years (~$12,000), HVAC in 8 years (~$8,000)
examples.calculation: Monthly reserve needed: ($12,000 ÷ 120 months) + ($8,000 ÷ 96 months) = $100 + $83 = $183/month (9.2% of rent)
examples.outcome: Setting aside $183/month ensures you're prepared for these major expenses without impacting cash flow

terms.shortDefinition: The fee charged by a property manager to handle day-to-day operations, typically 8-10% of collected rent.
terms.fullDefinition: Property management fees are charged by professional managers to handle tenant relations, rent collection, maintenance coordination, and other day-to-day operations. Fees typically range from 8-12% of collected rent, with additional charges for tenant placement (50-100% of first month's rent) and lease renewals. Even if you self-manage, many investors include a management fee in their analysis to understand true property performance and prepare for future scaling.
proTips: Include management fees in your analysis even if you self-manage
Ask about all fees: placement, renewal, maintenance markup, etc.
A good property manager can save money through efficient operations
Self-managing works for 1-2 properties but consider PM as you scale

terms.shortDefinition: A document listing all units, tenants, lease terms, and rental amounts for a property.
terms.fullDefinition: A rent roll is a detailed list of all rental units in a property showing current tenants, unit details, monthly rent, lease start and end dates, security deposits, and any notes. It's essential for due diligence when purchasing, refinancing, or evaluating a property. The rent roll tells you actual income (not just projected), lease expirations to plan for, and any below-market or problematic tenants.
proTips: Always verify the rent roll with bank statements or leases during due diligence
Look for month-to-month tenants—they could leave anytime
Compare rent roll rents to market rates to find upside potential
Check for lease expiration clustering that could create turnover waves

terms.shortDefinition: The expenses incurred when preparing a unit for a new tenant, including cleaning, repairs, and upgrades.
terms.fullDefinition: Turn costs (or turnover costs) are the expenses required to prepare a unit for a new tenant after the previous one moves out. This includes cleaning, painting, carpet cleaning or replacement, repairs, and any upgrades. Turn costs also include the lost rent during vacancy. High turnover is expensive—minimizing turn costs and turnover frequency directly improves your bottom line.
proTips: Average turn costs are $1,000-$3,000 plus lost rent during vacancy
Invest in durable materials that reduce turn costs (LVP flooring, quality paint)
A thorough move-in inspection documents condition and protects your security deposit claims
Long-term tenants save thousands in turn costs—treat good tenants well
